counts as a covered expense?","description":"Medical care expenses like doctor visit copays and prescriptions are typically eligible expenses to pay with your HSA. You can also use your HSA for health-related items. When checking out in a store, you can use your HSA debit card to pay for items that qualify as eligible expenses under an HSA. You can present your card for payment at the time of service. If you are not able to use your card to pay for a qualified expense, you can file a claim to request reimbursement.\n\nCheck out our webview{full list} of covered expenses.","webviewLinks":["https://www.irs.gov/pub/irs-pdf/p502.pdf"],"webviewToolbars":[false]},{"id":"intro","label":"When to pay out-of-pocket vs. HSA","description":"So how do you decide whether to pay expenses out of pocket, or use your HSA? Savings*","type":"dollar"}]}]},{"id":"contentModal","header":"How did we come up with these numbers?","marginBottom":"37px","elements":[{"id":"intro","header":"We use a variety of data to determine your personalized guidance:","descriptions":["Yearly goal is based on the maximum amount permitted by the IRS for individual or family coverage and catchup contributions if over age 55.","Contributions per pay period is the calculation of your yearly goal divided by the number of pay periods in a year.","Yearly tax savings assumes a default tax rate of 22% multiplied by your contribution guidance to determine federal tax savings only.","Your suggested contribution amount does not consider additional dollars your employer may contribute, and may need to be reduced to keep your total contributions within the yearly IRS limits."],"bold":false}]},{"id":"input","answerId":"adjustGoal","type":"radioButtonInput","label":"Do you want to adjust this
